Also known as the Rebel T7 in America, Kiss X90 in Japan, and 1500D in Southeast Asia, is an entry-level budget camera released in 2018. 

As a basic camera without frills, this is perfect for newbies who want to learn the rudiments of photography. It’s compatible with all EF and EF-S lenses, so finding the right glass will be a breeze.

Image Quality and Performance

24.1MP APS-C CMOS sensor and DIGIC 4+ processor guarantee good image quality (in bright conditions, at least). Producing sharp and vibrant end results, it is perfect for beautiful sceneries, simple portraits, and travel. Although, the ISO range (100-6400, expandable to 12800) is limited compared to newer models. It works well in daylight, but the 9-point AF system is basic and slow, meaning in low-light light settings, it struggles to keep up and produces noise. If you plan to shoot in dim environments, a tripod or external lighting is a must. It’s great for still subjects but not so much for fast-moving environments like sports.

Design and Build

This has a plastic body and follows the traditional DSLR design. So it doesn’t have a high-end feel or anything, but definitely comfortable to maneuver. The button layout is easy to navigate for first-time DSLR users. It comes with a 3.0-inch LCD screen with 920k-dot resolution, good for image review, but sadly, there is no touchscreen. The optical pentamirror viewfinder has 95% coverage, which is standard for entry-level cameras. But since it doesn’t cover the whole frame, you may need to tinker with it a tad bit when composing shots.

Connectivity and Battery Life

One of the upgrades from its predecessor (Rebel T6) is the built-in Wi-Fi and NFC; you can transfer photos to your smartphone easily using the Canon Camera Connect app. But it doesn’t have Bluetooth which is common in newer cameras.

Battery life is good, around 500 shots per charge, which is typical for entry-level DSLRs. But frequent use of Wi-Fi will drain the battery faster.

Pros and Cons of Canon EOS Rebel T7

So, What’s the Verdict?

Well, if you require better levels of autofocus, a fancier touchscreen, or 4K UHD video, you might want to look into more of the advanced models with the updated tech. But for its affordable pricing, it works well for beginners.

And yeah, It has its set of limitations but in the end, is a reliable friend who gets the job done!
